The supplier registration team AD-DED suppliers registered will be available across all Entities. Non-AD-DED suppliers will be available solely within the Entity that initiated the supplier registration request.

sections.title: 5.6.2.1 Supplier Registration of Foreign Suppliers
sections.content:
5.6.2.1 Supplier Registration of Foreign Suppliers

Foreign suppliers must provide the following documents, attested by the UAE Embassy of their respective country, to be registered as a Supplier in the Supplier Master Database:

Commercial/industrial license or valid justification on company letterhead.

Tax registration number certificate or valid justification on company letterhead.

Articles of association / partnership agreement.

Bank account confirmation letter.

Foreign suppliers that fall under the following criteria listed below are exempted from attestation of the above-mentioned documents subject to management approval.

Foreign suppliers with current/expected spend of less than five hundred thousand (500,000) AED/year across all Entities combined.

Foreign suppliers providing goods/services related to the following categories:

Hotels.

Other travel modes (such as road/rail transportation).

Training fees for universities and training programs.

Telecommunication services.

Goods/services on Presidential flights.

Figure 6:

Attestation requirements

sections.title: 5.6.2.2 Supplier Qualification
sections.content:
5.6.2.2 Supplier Qualification

Supplier Registration team shall qualify suppliers to enable instant access to the pool of suppliers deemed suitable to provide goods, services, and project to government Entities.

The following elements may be considered in the qualification of suppliers:

Business registration and legal status.

Demonstration of financial stability.

Credible reputation and references of the supplier.

Litigation history.

Experience in supplying goods, services and projects and related certifications.

Successful completion of contracts with reputable clients.

Qualification criteria shall be adjusted relatively to type of supplier and its year of establishment.

Verification of the ownership structure and key personnel of the supplier to identify potential conflicts of interest.

Supplier CSR practices, and measurable Green/Sustainable Procurement goals.

Supplier information shall be gathered and stored utilising the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP), and once qualified, supplier status shall be changed to “Qualified”.

sections.title: 5.6.2.3 Update and Deactivate Disqualify Registered Suppliers
sections.content:
5.6.2.3 Update and Deactivate Disqualify Registered Suppliers

The supplier is responsible for updating registered suppliers’ information.

Procurement shall periodically review the list of registered suppliers, with the aim to remove inactive suppliers. All requests shall be directed to and validated by the Supplier Registration Team.

Supplier Registration team shall deactivate all suppliers without an existing valid trade license.
hierarchy: 5.6.2.3 Update and Deactivate Disqualify Registered Suppliers

sections.title: 5.6.3 Supplier Segmentation
sections.content:
5.6.3 Supplier Segmentation

Procurement shall segment suppliers to manage and grow supplier relationships to increase mutual benefits, optimise value from the relationship, and prevent supply disruptions.

Gov. Procurement has outlined the following pre-defined segments to ensure supplier segmentation criteria is coherent with overarching business objectives.

Strategic suppliers

– show potential of innovation and collaboration, have a proven track record, and are some of the highest spend suppliers.

Critical suppliers

– are critical to everyday operations and any failure by such suppliers have a significant impact on the Entity’s operations.

Operational suppliers

– have contracted commitments that require operational tracking and delivery monitoring.

Transactional suppliers

– have minimal contracted spend with the least impact.

Figure 7

: Supplier Segmentation

Suppliers shall be allocated to a segment based on following two parameters:

Business Impact of the Supplier

- implies how vital the supplier is to Procurement business operations and future initiatives.

Supplier Risk /Complexity

- implies the dependence of Procurement on the supplier, the risks associated with the relationship, and ease of switching the supplier, if required.

Assessment of following criteria shall determine where suppliers rank on the ‘Supplier Risk’ and ‘Business Impact’ axes:

Category classification and category strategy.

Bargaining power of the supplier.

Spend with the supplier.

Supplier risk and complexity.

Supplier CSR practices and its impact on the Green/ Sustainable Procurement goals.

Supplier’s potential to grow, innovate and collaborate.

Proven capability, track record, and performance.

Availability of ICV certification.

Procurement shall regularly perform supplier segmentation to ensure that a supplier’s classification reflects the supplier’s performance and relationship with the Business.

Common categories supplier segmentation shall be managed by Gov. Procurement where these suppliers are considered ‘strategic suppliers.

Entity-specific supplier segmentation shall be managed by each Entity respectively.

Procurement is required to consolidate and report supplier segmentation. This report will be subject to approval as per PDoA.

Figure 8 provides guidelines that shall be utilised by Procurement to manage relationships for each of the supplier segments. The subsequent sections will provide further details on each of the actions.

Figure 8:

Supplier Segmentation Management Guidelines

sections.title: 5.6.4 Supplier Performance Evaluation
sections.content:
5.6.4 Supplier Performance Evaluation

It is the responsibility of Procurement to oversee supplier performance evaluations.

Procurement shall drive both ongoing and post-contract supplier performance evaluations for all suppliers with spend commitment greater than fifty thousand (50,000) AED.

Supplier performance shall be recorded and made available on the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP).

Supplier performance metrics shall be approved by the Head of Procurement and shall be reviewed periodically to align with the business objectives.

Supplier performance evaluation must be conducted at least once during a fiscal year. Procurement is recommended to perform bi-annual or quarterly supplier performance evaluations for Strategic suppliers.

Procurement shall use supplier performance to drive relationships which lead to close collaboration, ensure continuity of supply, reduce risk, encourage innovation, and generate value for the government Entity and supplier.

The following parameters may be analysed by Procurement during supplier performance Evaluations:

Contractual and operational performance including but not limited to adherence to schedules, agreed rates or contracted prices, on-time delivery, flexibility in adjusting to changes in requirement, consistency of goods/service delivery.

Responsiveness to inquiries, issues and changes and avoiding escalation.

Number of claims and cases raised against the supplier.

Supplier risk profile.

Compliance with regulatory, health, safety, and environmental guidelines.

Compliance to DGE CSR standards and Green/Sustainable Procurement goals.

Participation in the sourcing activity.

History of withdrawal from contract execution after being successfully awarded.

Supplier Performance evaluation shall include inputs from the end-users/requestors, Finance, Legal and the Contract Administrator. Procurement practitioners shall be responsible for signing off the results of supplier performance evaluation for the categories they manage.

Procurement shall share performance evaluation results with respective suppliers to align performance understanding enabling a collaborative approach for optimising and increasing the effectiveness of the supply chain.

sections.title: 5.6.4.1 Supplier Feedback and Improvements
sections.content:
5.6.4.1 Supplier Feedback and Improvements

Procurement shall conduct supplier performance reviews at least once every year, involving end-users, Finance, and experts, to discuss performance related issues, obtain feedback, and seek improvement.

Suppliers shall prepare and submit corrective action plans to remedy performance related issues. Corrective action plans shall be reviewed, approved, and monitored by Procurement.

It is recommended to request 360° feedback from suppliers, whereby feedback shall be treated confidentially, ethically, and not used in future appraisals.

sections.title: 5.6.5 Supplier Relationship Development
sections.content:
5.6.5 Supplier Relationship Development

Procurement shall drive, whereby:

Procurement shall leverage the supplier segmentation process to carefully curate a shortlist of strategic suppliers and determine potential collaborative partners.

Entity-specific categories ‘Strategic Suppliers’ shall be managed by each Entity respectively.

Procurement may establish dedicated supplier development and collaboration teams for each strategic supplier.

The Supplier Development and Collaboration team may coordinate with their suppliers to align on the desired frequency of meetings to discuss strategic objectives, performance metrics, and opportunities of mutual growth.

For each strategic supplier the Supplier Development and Collaboration team should develop a ‘Supplier Development and Collaboration Plan’. The plan should specify the development and collaboration opportunities agreed with the supplier.

The development and collaboration opportunities may be derived from the ‘Procurement Strategy’ and relevant ‘Category Strategy’.

The ‘Supplier Development and Collaboration Plan’ may encompass the following topic including, but not limited to:

Cost Reduction and Value Creation.

Innovation, Research & Development.

Compliance and Ethical Standards.

Supplier CSR practices and Green/Sustainable Procurement goals.

Development on the ICV scoring.

sections.title: 5.6.6 Supplier Risk Management
sections.content:
5.6.6 Supplier Risk Management

Supplier risk management (SRM) aims to identify high risk suppliers and optimize the risk mitigation efforts, where Procurement shall conduct supplier risk profiling periodically (recommended annually at a minimum).

A supplier’s qualification assessment provides first insight into a supplier’s risk profile and is to be incorporated into the risk profile assessment for Operational (where applicable), Critical, and Strategic Suppliers.

Procurement shall perform risk profile assessment for suppliers.

Once the supplier risk profile is defined, Procurement shall, in collaboration with the appropriate stakeholders (including the Supplier where applicable), monitor the risk and perform the necessary mitigation actions.

Supplier risk profiling shall be incorporated into procurement activities to enhance risk across the organisation. Including but not limited to the following circumstances:

Incorporate supplier risk profiles into the supplier evaluation process.

Incorporate risk-mitigating clauses in contracts, especially for high-risk suppliers.

Implement improvement initiatives for suppliers with moderate risk levels to enhance their capabilities and reduce risks.

Risk profiling criteria must align with the overarching business objectives. The following types of risk should be considered when designing risk profiles:

Financial Risk.

Operational Risk, including supply chain risk.

Ethical and Social Responsibility Risk.

Legislative Risk.

Technology and cybersecurity risk.

Human Resource Risk, including labour shortages and employee turnover.

Procurement, together with the respective stakeholders, shall take into consideration the Supplier’s Risk Profile in future upcoming procurement activities with the respective supplier, including, but not limited to:

Future Sourcing activities in which the supplier is involved, if any.

Evaluating the need for dual- or multi-source of products and/or services acquired from the supplier.

The creation, extension, or renewal of contracts for the supplier, if any.

Additional monitoring of the order delivery and invoicing process for the supplier, where applicable.

Incorporation of risk mitigation objectives into the supplier performance measurement, where applicable.

sections.title: 5.6.7 Blacklisting Supplier
sections.content:
5.6.7 Blacklisting Supplier

Blacklisting of a supplier entails the disqualification of the supplier from providing any goods, services, or projects to Entities until such time the circumstances resulting in blacklisting have been alleviated.

Suppliers can be blacklisted in case of serious misconduct and/or significant risk arising if Entity continues the relationship with the supplier. Reasons for supplier backlisting include but are not limited to:

Falsification of information provided to an Entity.

Declining to sign the contract after being awarded.

Supplier blacklisted by the UAE government and/or international sanctions.

Engaging in unethical practices violate the code of conduct, such as bribery, corruption, or other dishonest behaviours.

Failing to comply with relevant laws, regulations, or industry standards, leading to legal or ethical violations.

Non-performance of the supplier on open engagements with ADGE’s over a longer period of time as measured via supplier performance management.

Blacklisting can be performed at various levels at discretion of Gov. Procurement

Gov. Procurement Level

– supplier is denied from providing goods, services, and projects to all Entities.

Entity-Level

– supplier is denied from providing goods, services, and projects to a specific Entity, but can continue to serve other Entities.

Category-Level

– supplier is denied from providing goods, services, and projects within specific categories, either for a specific Entity or across all Entities.

Procurement Committee approval and confirmation of the Entity Chairmen are required for blacklisting supplier(s). The Chairman must assess the severity of the situation before approving the request to blacklist a supplier.

The Supplier Registration Team shall update the Supplier Master Database upon receipt of approval to blacklist a supplier and communicate with the Procurement team and end-users involved with this supplier.

sections.title: 5.7 Procure to Pay (P2P)
sections.content: 5.7 Procure to Pay (P2P)

sections.title: 5.7.1 Introduction
sections.content:
5.7.1 Introduction

The objective of requisition to pay is to provide an efficient and cost-effective method for purchasing goods, services and projects in alignment with Procurement Principles, Procurement & Category Strategies, and business needs, while at the same time ensuring the proper degree of control.

Procurement and Finance will operate on a ‘No PO No Pay’ basis, which entails that before financial commitments are made towards a supplier, a purchase requisition needs to be raised, approved and converted into a purchase order. The following exceptions apply:

Spend exempted from the Procurement Framework, as listed in the List of Exemptions (Section 2.1.3).

Spend purchased via Petty Cash or P-card (Section 2.7.3).

Emergency purchases in accordance with the guidelines of Section 2.7.9.

Finance will address invoices that violate the ‘No PO No Pay’ Policy in accordance with the guidelines in the Finance Policy.

Procure to Pay encompasses the following activities: requisition, tendering, ordering, receiving and invoice payment for goods/services/projects.

End-users shall initiate the requisition and are accountable for the receiving stage. Procurement shall be responsible for creating and managing purchase orders, whereas the invoice handling and payment section is led by Finance.

This section is organised as follows:  Section 2.7.2 provides guidance on requisition creation and governance. Section 2.7.3 outlines the definition, structure, and criteria of the approved buying channels for ADGOV. Sections 2.7.4 to 2.7.15 detail the guidelines governing the execution of procure to pay.

sections.title: 5.7.2 Guidance for Raising Requisition
sections.content:
5.7.2 Guidance for Raising Requisition

End-users/requestors shall raise purchase requisitions through the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP) incorporating at least the following details:

Specifications, scope, and schedule (if required).

Required quantities considering existing inventory and actual demand.

Relevant category.

Realistic purchase requisition price.

Reasonable need by date.

End-users shall ensure that purchase requisitions are created before the commitment to the supplier is made and before purchasing the good and/or service. In case this is not feasible, the end-user should create a post-factum purchase requisition which requires approval via the appropriate PDoA. Upon approval, Procurement will facilitate creation of an associated Post-Factum PO.

Purchases bought via Petty Cash, P-card, or for goods & services on the List of Exemptions (Section 2.1.3) do not require creation of a post-factum PR/PO.

End-users/requestors are prohibited from splitting purchase requisitions into several transactions and routing transactions through different buying channels to avoid defined threshold values in the PDoA. Procurement shall be responsible to monitor compliance.

Procurement shall endeavour to satisfy the received requisitions, having them consolidated with an optimal number of purchase orders. When considering whether transactions should be combined, only similar transactions must be considered.

Requestors can order on behalf of other end-users when applicable to streamline government operations. Authorisation to do so is governed by the Digital Procurement Platform.

sections.title: 5.7.3 Buying Channels
sections.content:
5.7.3 Buying Channels

All purchasing activities shall be conducted exclusively through authorised buying channels designated by the Entity. These channels are designed to ensure ease of use, adequate data registration, and compliance with Procurement Framework and relevant laws and regulations.

End-users/requestors, in collaboration with Procurement, shall utilise the available buying channels to create and submit a purchase request through the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP).

Approved buying channels include the following: MRP, catalogue, non-catalogue purchase order, invoice-only, petty cash, P-card and spot buy.

Procurement practitioners responsible for managing the categories shall select the appropriate buying channel(s) for their category based on, but not limited to, the following criteria:

Value of purchase.

Type of purchase.

Volume of purchase.

Category criticality.

Committed delivery date.

Required approvals.

Urgency.

Approvals for purchase requisitions raised via the various spend thresholds will be based on value thresholds as defined in the PDoA.

End-users/requestors must adhere to the use of the approved buying channel(s), unless in the event of an emergency situation as specified in Section 2.7.9.

sections.title: 5.7.3.1 Material Requirements Planning Orders (MRP Orders)
sections.content:
5.7.3.1 Material Requirements Planning Orders (MRP Orders)

MRP orders are applicable for inventory items and are managed via the replenishment management solution. Section 2.11.4 of the Inventory Policy provides additional details on MRP orders.

sections.title: 5.7.3.2 Catalogue
sections.content:
5.7.3.2 Catalogue

As one of the preferred buying channels, end-users/requestors are encouraged to consistently utilise catalogues if available. End-users/requestors should identify if their need is served by one of the available catalogues before considering creation of a purchase request via one of the other buying channels.

Catalogues consist of goods and services with pre-approved prices and specifications from contracted suppliers, and can take two forms:

Internal catalogues

managed by Procurement.

Punch-out catalogues

that are managed by the supplier.

Procurement shall aim to keep both internal and punch-out catalogues up to date to ensure ease of use and compliant requisitions by the end-users/requestors.

Procurement shall evaluate the applicability of setting up a new internal or punch-out catalogue following the establishment of a new contract for products and/or services.

Procurement shall de-activate the catalogue(s) upon termination of the contract(s).

Procurement shall periodically review and update catalogues to reflect changes in supplier offerings, pricing, and Entity needs.

sections.title: 5.7.3.3 Non-Catalogue Request (Regular Purchase Requisition)
sections.content:
5.7.3.3 Non-Catalogue Request (Regular Purchase Requisition)

In the absence of a catalogue, the end-users/requestors shall raise a purchase requisition as ‘non-catalogue request’.

Non-catalogue requests may be used to request a new sourcing activity or to release a purchase order in accordance with an existing contract.

Non-catalogue requests shall be created and submitted for approval as per Section 2.7.4.

sections.title: 5.7.3.4 Purchasing Cards (P-cards)
sections.content:
5.7.3.4 Purchasing Cards (P-cards)

Purchasing cards (P-cards) may be used as a buying channel only when:

It is the only acceptable form of payment, and;

The purchase is ad-hoc with no contract in place, and;

Value of the goods / services is less than fifty thousand (50,000) AED, and;

The goods / services are part of the following categories:

Online subscriptions and licenses.

Travel Visa, all immigration expenses, and other travel expense (i.e., tickets, hotels, transportation)

Car maintenance & road subscription.

Any other expense – subject to pre-approval as per PDoA with justification.

Finance shall regularly monitor P-card usage patterns to identify potential trends, discrepancies, or opportunities for process improvement.

sections.title: 5.7.3.5 Petty Cash
sections.content:
5.7.3.5 Petty Cash

Petty cash purchases are defined as small cash purchases used for minor expenses, enabling quick purchases without formal purchase order processes.

Petty cash transactions are limited to direct purchases from suppliers requiring immediate cash payment and with a value of less than, or equal to, five thousand (5,000) AED per purchase and without exceeding five thousand (5,000) AED per supplier.

All petty cash purchases shall be managed by the end-user and the Finance department. Petty cash purchases must be recorded by Finance for future spend analysis requirements. Payments are managed in accordance with the Finance Policy.

sections.title: 5.7.3.6 Spot Buy
sections.content:
5.7.3.6 Spot Buy

Spot buy is applicable for requisitions of goods, services, and/or projects with a value of less than fifty thousand (50,000) AED.

Spot buy is subject to the following guidelines:

End-users shall provide a minimum of two quotations.

Quotations shall be comparable in terms of specifications, quantity, and quality.

Quotations shall be only provided from licensed, registered suppliers. Supplier registration can be found in Section

Error! Reference source not found.

.

Spot buy acquisitions only apply to a ‘one-off’ need and shall not result in a commitment for a longer period and/or repeated service, in which case an official sourcing activity should be applied.

The end-user shall create and submit a purchase requisition and purchase order for Spot Buy purchases.

Approval of a Spot Buy shall involve Procurement and take place via the PDoA guidelines.

sections.title: 5.7.3.7 Exemption List Payments (Invoice-only)
sections.content:
5.7.3.7 Exemption List Payments (Invoice-only)

The invoice-only buying channel is appropriate for predefined goods and services included in the exemption list issued by Gov. Procurement (Section 2.1.3).

End-users shall adhere to the following guidelines when utilising invoice-only:

The end-users/requestors shall notify the supplier of the correct submission process for payment of exception list invoices, in line with the applicable procurement and finance policies and in alignment with Finance.

The end-user/requestor shall provide the supplier with the correct valid exception code – provided by Finance – for the supplier to refer to in the invoice.

Finance shall return invoices which do not have a valid exception code to the supplier.

Procurement and Finance, in collaboration, shall be responsible for verifying and adding (when approved) goods and services to the exemption list, upon suggestion of end-users/requestors.

A purchase requisition and purchase order should not be created when utilising invoice-only buying channel.

Procurement is not involved in invoice-only purchases. In case of non-compliant use of the invoice-only buying channel, Finance shall notify the requestor and budget holder to define the appropriate course of action – which could be the rejection of the invoice.

sections.title: 5.7.4 Approving Requisitions
sections.content:
5.7.4 Approving Requisitions

Purchase requisitions shall be approved by the relevant authority in accordance with the PDoA.

The Budget Owner shall ensure that there is sufficient approved budget for the purchase requisition.

It is the responsibility of end-users/requestors to contact Finance and obtain the necessary budget approval prior to initiating a purchase requisition for an unplanned purchase.

Procurement practitioners responsible for managing categories shall receive the purchase requisition after it has been approved in the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP). They shall perform an initial check for completeness, verify that the appropriate buying channel was used, and take the necessary action for purchase order creation.

If required, Procurement shall request end-users/requestors to update the purchase requisition to reflect the appropriate action.

If required, Procurement shall take the necessary actions to source the requested goods/services, in line with the guidelines as specified in the Sourcing Policy (2.4).

Approved purchase requisitions shall lead directly to a purchase order if goods/services/projects requested in the purchase requisition are covered under an existing contract or the purchase requisition is created through a catalogue.

sections.title: 5.7.5 Purchase Order
sections.content:
5.7.5 Purchase Order

A purchase order is a written agreement between the Entity and suppliers to procure goods, services, and projects in reference to a contract, price list agreement or on a standalone basis.

Procurement shall ensure existence of an approved purchase requisition prior to creating a purchase order through the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP).

Procurement shall ensure every purchase order line item is assigned to a category as per the category hierarchy.

Purchase orders must be created before a financial commitment to a Supplier is made.

sections.title: 5.7.6 Guidance for Releasing Purchase Orders
sections.content:
5.7.6 Guidance for Releasing Purchase Orders

Non-catalogue purchase orders shall be released by Procurement to the supplier after approvals have been obtained in the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP) as per the PDoA.

Catalogue purchase orders shall be released automatically after the purchase requisition has been approved.

The issuer of the purchase order is recommended to request an order confirmation from the supplier.

The supplier must acknowledge the receipt of the purchase order via the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP) within the contractual timeframe.

If the issuer of the purchase order does not receive an acknowledgment, they are responsible for contacting the supplier, and/or contact Procurement to establish appropriate escalation to ensure visibility of the order status.

The issuer of the purchase order shall reach out to Procurement to establish the appropriate course of action in case of, but not limited to:

Issuer of the purchase order does not receive an acknowledgement from the supplier within the defined timeframe (typically 5 working days).

Issuer of the purchase order is unable to identify the correct supplier contact person/ contact details.

In the event supplier cannot confirm the complete purchase order.

In the event supplier rejects the purchase order.

sections.title: 5.7.7 Purchase Order Amendments
sections.content:
5.7.7 Purchase Order Amendments

Procurement may amend the purchase order at the minimum for the following scenarios:

When the quantity for the good/service in the contract is below the quantity in a purchase requisition.

When the value the good/service in the contract is below the value of a purchase requisition.

Procurement shall not amend the purchase order to accommodate the supplier’s delays in executing the scope of work unless certain action or instruction from the government Entity has caused or contributed to such a delay.

When the variance to the original contracted price exceeds the approved threshold, Procurement shall require approval from the appropriate authority as per the PDoA, for the total of the original agreement and the exceeded variation.

For amendments of purchase orders for projects, Procurement shall verify the agreement/contract for the project and if necessary, consult with the technical evaluation team/individual. The amendment shall not be issued to accomplish work outside the original business case or scope of work.

sections.title: 5.7.8 Purchase Order Cancellation
sections.content:
5.7.8 Purchase Order Cancellation

Procurement shall initiate the cancellation of the purchase order under the following scenarios:

When goods, services and projects are no longer needed by the requestor.

When goods, services and projects change in specification or scope.

When a supplier is unable to deliver goods, services and projects as per the agreed delivery conditions.

Procurement shall cancel the purchase order in the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP) after confirmation from end-users/requestors.

When required and where applicable, Procurement will support Finance in providing justification for payment of invoices received against cancelled purchase orders.

sections.title: 5.7.9 Emergency Situations
sections.content:
5.7.9 Emergency Situations

Procurement shall allow emergency purchases after approval as per PDoA, in the following situations:

Operational emergency – immediate disruption of operations resulting in significant expense or liability for the government entity, or when critical systems are down, or when other assets and the environment are under serious threat and need to be addressed immediately.

Personal emergency – immediate danger to human health and safety that need to be addressed immediately.

Natural disaster – Unforeseen catastrophic events that impact a specific portion of the population and requires temporary deviation from standard procurement guidelines for essential immediate response.

An emergency purchase is an exception process, and it may only be utilised to purchase what is necessary to cover the emergency. Emergency purchases are not permitted under any other circumstances.

Procurement shall ensure that end-users/requestors do not use emergency purchase as an excuse for failing to plan demand up front. All emergency purchases must be documented in the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP) and shall be monitored by Procurement.

sections.title: 5.7.10 Managing Receiving
sections.content:
5.7.10 Managing Receiving

The supplier shall deliver goods and services on time as per the contract and purchase order terms. Any potential delay requires immediate notice to end-users/requestors and Procurement with accurate delivery estimates.

The delivery note (Goods Receipt Note or Service Receipt Note) shall be created by the supplier for all goods, services and projects delivered.

End-users and other relevant parties shall ensure the receiving of goods, services and projects through Digital Procurement Platform (ERP) without unnecessary delay, which at the minimum shall include:

Physical receiving.

Inspection of completeness & quality.

Recording receipt in the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP).

sections.title: 5.7.10.1 Inspection of Receiving
sections.content:
5.7.10.1 Inspection of Receiving

Criteria for defining inspection of deliverables, if required, shall be provided by end-users and should always be documented in the purchase order or contract. Goods subject to health and safety considerations (e.g., medicines) and industry specific regulations shall always require inspection.

If testing certifications or third-party inspections are needed, these shall be defined by the end-users/requestors during creation of the purchase request.

End-users or subject matter experts shall be responsible for performing the inspection of goods, services and projects.

In case of goods/services/projects with high value, the Entity may choose to form a committee to conduct the inspection.

The inspection shall determine conformance to the acceptance criteria, requirements, specifications, and terms and conditions of the purchase order.

sections.title: 5.7.10.2 Acceptance or Rejection of Receiving
sections.content:
5.7.10.2 Acceptance or Rejection of Receiving

Delivery of goods is accepted by the end-user or Material Management Team if the quantity and specification match with that provided in the contract and/or purchase order or are within acceptable tolerances specified in the contract and/or purchase order. For the delivery of services, end-users provide inputs on delivery with respect to milestones, KPIs/SLA, timelines etc.

In case of non-acceptance, delivery of goods can be rejected completely or partially. If a partial delivery is made, a partial receipt shall be entered in the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP). Discrepancies are communicated to Procurement and the supplier.

Depending on the reason for rejection, the supplier either replaces the defective/damaged goods or delivers the missing goods. In case the supplier cannot deliver a replacement, the purchase order can be terminated, and the supplier shall be informed.

The end-user shall escalate the matter internally to the next level of the organisational hierarchy, and Procurement will be notified if a supplier does not respond after multiple contact attempts and/or no satisfactory alignment can be reached on discrepancies regarding the good/service/project delivery.

Goods/Service receipt shall be approved as per the PDoA.

sections.title: 5.7.11 Managing Returns
sections.content:
5.7.11 Managing Returns

Procurement shall manage returns to suppliers and ensure receiving appropriate credit or replacement for the return. Returns shall be driven by the need to repair or replace goods or non-conformance on services and projects.

Procurement shall ensure the end-user/requestor initiates and formally requests the return.

Procurement shall be responsible for validating the request to return, coordinating the return with the supplier, and recording return transaction reasoning and details.

sections.title: 5.7.12 Disputes Related to Goods, Services and Projects Purchasing
sections.content:
5.7.12 Disputes Related to Goods, Services and Projects Purchasing

Disputes related to purchasing of goods, services and projects follow the guidelines from Penalties, Claims and Disputes as per Section 2.5.7.

As per the guidelines, claims shall be handled by end-users/requestors and Procurement can be consulted for support. If end-users/requestors and the supplier cannot reach an agreement on the claim, a dispute can arise. Disputes shall be managed by Procurement.

The Procurement shall manage all disputes raised by the end-users/requestors in, but not limited to, the following scenarios:

Goods shortage, and/or incomplete service or project delivery.

Substitute goods, resources, materials which have not been authorised or approved.

Goods, service, project delivery not conforming to technical specifications.

Goods not as per required shelf life.

Damaged goods.

Failure to perform or fulfil contractual obligations.

Loss of or damage to property.

Non-conformance to terms and conditions of the contract.

End-users/requestors shall communicate to Procurement in case of any dispute arising with a supplier. Procurement shall verify the dispute for merit and ability to claim compensation and may seek advice and involvement of Finance and Legal if required. Procurement shall send the notification to the supplier to replace or provide reimbursement for the supplier’s shortcomings. Section 2.5.7 offers additional guidelines on the management of claims and disputes.

Procurement shall facilitate dispute resolution with the supplier, and will investigate to clarify the accountability for the issue at hand.
hierarchy: 5.7.12 Disputes Related to Goods, Services and Projects Purchasing

sections.title: 5.7.13 Invoice Receipt and Processing
sections.content:
5.7.13 Invoice Receipt and Processing

Finance shall be responsible for executing the invoice receipt, processing, handling & payment.

Invoice submission guidelines shall be established by Finance. For further detail refer to the Finance Policy.

Finance shall be authorised for releasing payment to suppliers. The invoice shall be paid according to the payment terms specified in the order or contract it refers to.

Suppliers’ invoices/payments related queries should be handled directly by Finance.

Finance will manage invoice discrepancies. Procurement may be engaged for assistance in resolving invoice mismatch issues.

sections.title: 5.7.14 Payment Requirements
sections.content:
5.7.14 Payment Requirements

Finance shall facilitate the release of payments to the suppliers in a timely and accurate manner upon verification of required documentation.

Finance, while facilitating the release of payment to suppliers, shall adhere to the following:

A purchase order is approved as per the agreed contractual obligations and recorded in the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP).

The goods, services or projects invoiced must be received, accepted and recorded in the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP).

Payments shall be made as per payment terms specified in the purchase order or contract.

Payment shall be made based on a 3-way match between the purchase order, goods/service receipt, and invoice, considering the tolerances specified in the contract. A 3-way match is not required in case of authorized exemptions that eliminate the requirement for creation of a purchase requisition (Section 2.7.2) and purchase order (Section 2.7.5), or goods/service receipt (Section 2.7.10).

Payments shall be made only if relevant supporting documents are available in the Digital Procurement Platform (ERP), attached and verified.

sections.title: 5.7.15 Purchase Order Closure
sections.content:
5.7.15 Purchase Order Closure

The purchase order shall be considered fulfilled and closed upon fulfilment of all terms, conditions, and delivery requirements. The closure of the purchase order will be initiated in the following cases:

After the final invoicing is done and final payment has been initiated against the purchase order.

When both the supplier and the end-user/requestor reach a mutual agreement to close the purchase order.

Supplier shall be notified that purchase order is closed and no further submission of new invoices against the closed purchase order will be accepted.

At the conclusion of each fiscal year, the finance department will close all open purchase orders that remain outstanding. End-users/requestors shall be responsible in raising new purchase requisitions for purchase orders that have not been received.

Procurement shall not create any new purchase order as per the cut-off date specified in the Finance Policy.

sections.title: 5.8 Master Data Management
sections.content: 5.8 Master Data Management

sections.title: 5.8.1 Introduction
sections.content:
5.8.1 Introduction

Procurement Master Data Management (MDM) refers to the approach of managing and maintaining essential data required for supporting the Procurement function.

The DGE Master Data team is the owner of the procurement master data.

To ensure consistency, accuracy, and proper management of all data, Entities shall coordinate with the DGE Master Data team with regard to procurement master data.

Any request regarding, creation, modification, or deletion of master data shall be communicated to the DGE team in a timely manner.

sections.title: 5.8.2 Supplier Master Data Management
sections.content:
5.8.2 Supplier Master Data Management

The Supplier MDM section includes guidelines for registration, deactivation, and reactivation of suppliers. The Supplier Master Database contains a unique record of each supplier.

The Supplier Registration Team, at the Department of Government Enablement (DGE), is responsible for onboarding and maintaining the Supplier Master Database.

The principle of Segregation of Duties applies to supplier master data management in order to ensure the integrity of the supplier master data. Requests need to be provided in writing, including detailed description of the rationale for supplier record creation, change, or deactivation. All supplier master data alterations require approval as per the PDoA.

Changes impacting supplier financial details (e.g., bank details) require approval from approvers of, at least, two separate functions to adhere to internal controls.

sections.title: 5.8.2.1 Supplier Master Data Creation
sections.content:
5.8.2.1 Supplier Master Data Creation

Refers to adding a new supplier to the Supplier Master Database following the registration request guidelines outlined in Section 2.6.2.

For registration, suppliers must provide information such as (but not limited to) license and tax information, contact details, goods and services, authorised representatives, payment Information and primary/ secondary bank details. All foreign suppliers must provide Attestation Requirements documentation as applicable per Section 2.6.2.1.

The DGE Supplier Registration Team shall be responsible for:

Validating the information provided and ensuring documentation required is correct.

Determining supplier enablement and restrictions, such as the categories or Entities for which a supplier can provide its services.

Approving the registration of the supplier, as per the PDoA.

Ensuring that each supplier is only listed once in the Supplier Master Data, and no duplications arise.

Entities specified can conduct business (i.e., raise purchase order) with the supplier after the supplier has been qualified as per Section 2.6.2.2.

sections.title: 5.8.2.2 Modify Supplier Master Data
sections.content:
5.8.2.2 Modify Supplier Master Data

The supplier may need to update the information provided due to multiple reasons including (but not limited to):

Add/modify a category which can be served by the supplier.

Modify information due to an update on the Supplier’s end (e.g., address, bank details).

Modification due to a regulation change.

Changes in supplier master data are subject to validation and approval from DGE Master Data Team.

sections.title: 5.8.2.3 Deactivate Supplier/Reactivate Supplier
sections.content:
5.8.2.3 Deactivate Supplier/Reactivate Supplier

No longer commercially active suppliers should be deactivated. Deactivated suppliers are not visible in any search list, cannot participate in tenders, and cannot be awarded contracts.

All existing contracts as well as outstanding invoices with the supplier must be terminated before deactivating a supplier.

Reasons for deactivating suppliers include:

Supplier with expired commercial/industrial license.

Suppliers that Procurement does not wish to trade with in the future, such as blacklisted suppliers.

Supplier relationship was terminated, and no new supplier activities are foreseen (e.g., one-off suppliers).

Suppliers with no active contracts and without Procurement transactions for more than twenty-four (24) months.

Duplicated supplier in the system.

Supplier can be reactivated under the following criteria:

Updated trade license is provided.

Blacklisted supplier status has been lifted.

sections.title: 5.8.3 Item Master Data Management
sections.content:
5.8.3 Item Master Data Management

Item Master Data Management (Item MDM) consists of guidelines for the creation and maintenance of records of items representing unique goods/services/projects.

The Item Master Database is a database of unique materials with associated specifications, item numbers and purchasing specifications.

The Item Master Data team, as part of the DGE Master Data team is responsible for establishing and maintaining the accurate, consistent and complete record of items. The Item Master Data team will act based on input from Procurement and involved end-users.

For adding, modifying or deleting an item record in the Item Master Data, the Entity requestor shall raise a request that will be reviewed and approved as per PDoA.

sections.title: 5.8.4 User Master Data Management
sections.content:
5.8.4 User Master Data Management

User Master Data Management consists of the guidelines associated with the creation and maintenance of records of individuals involved in procurement activities.

User Master Data holds the record of applicable employees involved in the Procurement activities, both within Procurement, Finance, Legal, and related business functions.

The User Master Data holds the roles of the respective employees in the Digital Procurement Platform and ensures the correct rights and access are given to responsible parties participating in Procurement activities.

sections.title: 5.9 Key Performance Indicators
sections.content:
5.9 Key Performance Indicators

Key Performance Indicators help Procurement determine the performance of the Procurement function and define appropriate actions to achieve set goals. There are three types of Procurement KPIs:

Strategic – owned by Gov. Procurement.

Common – owned by Gov. Procurement.

Operational – owned by the Entity.

The Gov. Procurement is responsible for creating the calculation methods for each common and strategic KPIs. These methods will be applied consistently across all Entities, and Entities are expected to follow these established calculations. Any modifications to these methods will be made by Gov. Procurement only and promptly communicated to all Entities.

Recognising the distinct goals and contexts of each Entity, the Entities are encouraged to additionally define and implement Entity specific Operational KPIs, tailored to their unique requirements.

sections.title: 5.9.1 KPIs monitoring
sections.content:
5.9.1 KPIs monitoring

Gov. Procurement shall be responsible for monitoring and publishing strategic and common KPIs through consolidation of all data. Results of these shall be published and communicated on a regular basis to Entities.

In cases where KPIs are not met according to the predefined targets, the following actions to take corrective measures are to be implemented:

Root Cause Analysis: Used to determine the causes of the failure to meet KPIs. This examination will aid in a better comprehension of the underlying problem. Procurement shall develop corrective actions to deal with the problems found.

Escalation: Depending on the performance indicator, issue shall be promptly and transparently communicated and escalated to the appropriate stakeholders on the status of unmet KPIs to take corrective measures.

Performance improvement plans: Performance improvement plans shall be created by Procurement in consultation with the relevant Entities and stakeholders, when necessary, where performance gaps persist for an extended period. These plans will specify the precise actions, due dates, and roles for achieving the necessary KPI levels.

sections.title: 5.10 Procurement Reporting
sections.content:
5.10 Procurement Reporting

Reporting encompasses the creation of reports to monitor and analyse Procurement performance based on KPIs, as well as the compliance to the Procurement Framework. Reporting is based on:

Transactional data encompassing procurement transactions, including but not limited to sourcing activities, demand of Entities, contracts, POs, and GRNs.

Master data consisting of supplier, item, and user insights.

The DGE Master Data team is responsible for ensuring the accuracy of the Procurement Master Data components, while the availability and accuracy of transactional data is subject to the quality of transactional documents created by Procurement, Finance, and the end-user.

Procurement will generate reports based on the required reporting timelines, and subject to the needs of the stakeholders, including but not limited to:

Reporting on the common and strategic KPIs for procurement that have been established by Gov. Procurement.

Reporting on Entity-level operational KPIs.

Standard reporting based on category.

Significant risks and problems, as well as strategies for managing them.

Other applicable reporting as required.

Entities are recommended to leverage the standard reports available to ensure consistency and comparability across Entities.

For reporting on common and strategic KPIs, the minimum required criteria, frequency of reporting, as well as structure of reports and specifications shall be defined by Gov. Procurement.

sections.title: 5.10.1 Guidelines for Reporting
sections.content:
5.10.1 Guidelines for Reporting

Reporting under procurement shall be classified into:

Procurement Strategic Reporting: Involves high-level insights and reports that support strategic decision making in Procurement. Strategic reporting shall be in alignment with the Procurement Strategy and shall provide information of trends, opportunities for spend optimisation, and strategic initiatives linked to strategic KPIs and DGE objectives.

Strategic reporting shall be done at Gov. Procurement level for all common strategic KPIs. Gov. Procurement will share insights from strategic reporting with the Entities periodically, and where applicable.

Entities shall develop strategic reports for Entity-specific categories and Entity-specific strategic initiatives. If applicable, Strategic reports shall be aligned with the strategy department of the Entity when necessary, providing input on the criteria or conditions that need to be met. Entities are recommended to share the associated insights with Gov. Procurement for reference where applicable.

Strategic reporting at Entity level shall be prepared by Procurement.

Procurement Operational Reporting: Provides detailed information about the operational aspects of procurement and day-to-day activities. Operational Reporting is aimed to enhance Procurement operational efficiency and day-to-day compliance to Procurement policies and processes across the Procure-to-Pay activities.

Operational Reporting shall be conducted at the Entity-level and shall be prepared regularly as well as ad-hoc, based on occurring Procurement needs. The frequency of the report may vary depending on the nature of the report, Activities requiring continuous monitoring, are recommended to be reported on a daily or weekly basis.

Procurement Management Report: Procurement shall present the Procurement Management Report of the Procurement function bi-annually to the Chairman of the government entity. The elements of the Procurement Management Report shall include at the minimum the following:

Spend value per category.

Spend value per Supplier.

Contracted price for goods, services and projects.

Delivered savings against planned savings for each category validated by the Finance.

Signed price list agreements.

Contracts against the plan and issued orders.

Status of the procurement of projects against the plan Ageing of due invoices.

Supplier and the end-users’ satisfaction to be reported yearly.

Status of strategic initiatives against the plan.

Compliance with approved buying channels and contracts for each category.

Details of sole source or single source tenders awarded including value of award supplier particulars and approved justification.

Emergency purchases made including value of purchase, supplier particulars and approved justification.

Details of escalations or complaints received from internal or external parties regarding procurement operations.

Any important outstanding matters for the management’s decision and other relevant information.

Gov. Procurement shall work on consolidating common standard reports in case of cross-Entity reporting needs and linked to cross-Entity strategic and operational initiatives. This consolidation aims to simplify reporting procedures, removing the need for Entities to create separate reports. The Entities shall collaborate with Gov. Procurement to review and ensure data at Entity level is accurate and correct. Common reports will be available to the Entities for review, and analysis.

sections.title: 5.11 Inventory Management
sections.content: 5.11 Inventory Management

sections.title: 5.11.1 Inventory classification
sections.content:
5.11.1 Inventory classification

Inventory items are assets meant for consumption during the rendering of services, or for sale or distribution as part of regular Entity course of business activities. For Entities with items stored in warehouses, they shall:

Classify inventory items as “Stock Items”, “Disposal Items” and “Direct Consumption Items”. Table 2 provides detail on this classification.

Abide by the procedures pertaining to Direct Consumption Items.

Table 2 – Inventory management, Item classification

sections.title: 5.11.1.1 Stock Items
sections.content:
5.11.1.1 Stock Items

Inventory Items shall be classified as “Stock Items” when these are intended for future use, resale, or are needed to fulfil the Entity’s strategic objectives. To be classified as “Stock Items”, inventory items must meet one or more of the following criteria:

Items are intended for future sale or to be consumed in the rendering of services.

Item is spare part or component for equipment maintenance.

Item is needed to support planned business events or objectives.

Item is required as stock based on strategic decision of the Entity.

Certain items, which do not meet this criterion, may still be classified as "Stock Items" subject to the approval of the Head of the Entity in exceptional cases such as items relate to safety measures or with long lead delivery.

Only items classified as "Stock Items", may be kept in warehouses.

Capital asset purchases shall not be kept in warehouses, rather the value of it, as well as all direct purchase costs, shall be recorded in the fixed asset register at the time of acquisition.

"Stock Items" purchases shall be recorded as stock in accounting records. Value of the stock is only charged to the appropriate budget item when issued for use and consumption purposes.

sections.title: 5.11.1.2 Direct Consumption Items
sections.content:
5.11.1.2 Direct Consumption Items

“Direct Consumption Items” are items purchased as needed, only when there is a demand for them.

“Direct Consumption Items”, shall not be kept in warehouses, added to warehouse stock, nor recorded in warehouse records.

“Direct Consumption Items” shall be charged to the appropriate budget item immediately upon purchase.

sections.title: 5.11.1.3 Disposal Items
sections.content:
5.11.1.3 Disposal Items

Disposal items shall be kept in a separate place in warehouses until disposal is completed.

Disposal items shall be recorded separately from warehouses stock.

Items to be disposed and disposal method shall be defined by an established independent committee, and include but are not limited to expired items, damaged items, non-functional, or items beyond its useful life (refer to the Finance Policy and Sales Auctions for details on the accounting of disposal items).

sections.title: 5.11.2 Warehouse Management Practitioners and their Duties
sections.content:
5.11.2 Warehouse Management Practitioners and their Duties

Based on work requirements and organisational structure, one or more warehouse practitioner shall be appointed to manage and maintain stock, referred to as Warehouse Practitioner. In case of multiple warehouse practitioners, they shall have joint responsibility. A warehouse practitioner may have one or more assistants who shall have joint responsibility with the warehouse practitioner, and all shall sign the stock lists. In case of absence, an assistant warehouse practitioner may relieve the warehouse practitioner during absence.

Warehouse Practitioners, or equivalent, are personally accountable for items under their custody for keeping and safeguarding weight, quantity, size, and exposure to damage or loss. A warehouse practitioner can only be discharged upon evidence of unavoidable and beyond control.

Upon leave absence, transfer or disengagement or whatsoever absence of a warehouse practitioner, someone shall be assigned duties of the warehouse practitioner.

The principle of Segregation of Duties is applicable to all inventory and warehouse processes, including purchasing of inventory, receiving inventory, recording of inventory, physical verification, and disposal of inventory.

Warehouse Practitioners, or equivalent, should submit to the appropriate authority level in the organisation structure periodic to take the needful action regarding the following:

Surplus items.

Not needed items.

Obsolete items.

Unusable items.

Items exposed to deterioration.

Items with limited validity period.
hierarchy: 5.11.2 Warehouse Management Practitioners and their Duties

sections.title: 5.11.3 Stocking Policies and Provisions.
sections.content:
5.11.3 Stocking Policies and Provisions.

Warehouse Practitioners shall keep detailed records of quantity of every stock item, in line with the Finance. All books are to be matched monthly, and inconsistencies, if any, shall be investigated immediately. Proper action shall be taken to determine accountability.

Organisation units of a government Entity shall prepare estimates of their expected stock purchases during the next year. Such estimates shall be submitted to the Finance which shall take them into consideration upon preparing the draft budget.

Each government Entity should establish its own approach for procuring items classified as Stock Items. Due attention shall be given to providing all needs of all stock items in order to meet construction, maintenance and operations requirements. Delivery period and stocks availability should also be taken into consideration.

Chairman of the government Entity may approve building strategic stocks of items classified as "Direct Consumption" or exceed maximum level of "Stock Items" in exceptional cases.

Every effort should be made to minimise number of items classified as "Stock Items" and be reclassified as "Direct Consumption Items" and be procured under materials contracts or by purchase orders as appropriate.

sections.title: 5.11.4 Material Requirements Planning Orders (MRP orders)
sections.content:
5.11.4 Material Requirements Planning Orders (MRP orders)

MRP orders are applicable for Inventory “Stock Items” and that are managed via the replenishment management solution.

MRP orders are an automated activity based on pre-approved or existing contracts for pre-defined requirements. If the current contract is expired, the reordering request will be routed through the Procurement department to determine the appropriate sourcing method or buying channel.

The reordering shall be done by the Inventory practitioners through ERP considering the elements for reordering.

The end-user or inventory management practitioner initiating the MRP order is accountable for collaborating with the Warehouse to verify that stock levels in the system are accurate and that the requested item is not presently available in stock.

Generation of MRP orders requires up-to-date item master data which is to be maintained in line with the guidelines in Section 2.8.3.

MRP orders will be generated based on, but not limited to forecasts, planning schedules, delivery lead times, and inventory levels. The system will calculate material requirements to meet planned demands and will consistently lead to the creation of a PR.

The re-ordering request shall be placed by the end-user or the inventory management practitioner and reviewed and approved in line with the PDoA.

sections.title: 5.11.4.1 Reordering Elements
sections.content:
5.11.4.1 Reordering Elements

The following elements outline the guidelines for reordering stock items and shall be recorded in the ERP:

Lead Time

: refers to the total amount of time from placing a request until the item arrives and is received in the warehouse. Lead time shall consider historical delivery data, shipping method, supplier agreed terms, internal requesting approval time, or any other relevant considerations. Lead time should be established for each stock item if applicable.

Inventory practitioners will define and regularly assess lead times, adjusting review frequency based on item nature and value. Monthly reviews are recommended for frequently re-ordered items.

Inventory practitioners shall collaborate with Procurement to update and define the most accurate lead time of items to be delivered based on supplier agreed terms.

Minimum Order Quantity (MOQ):

is the minimum amount quantity that can be purchased. MOQ shall be defined previously based on agreed terms with supplier, storage constraints, demand of the item, historical data, or any other relevant considerations. Procurement may be consulted initially to evaluate possible MOQ improvement during supplier negotiations and contracting. MOQ should be defined for each stock item if applicable.

Reorder Point:

Refers to the minimum level of stock for a specific item that will trigger reordering. This shall be defined by Inventory practitioners performing the reordering. In determining the reorder point, the following may be considered:

Minimum stock level.

Lead time.

Actual need for the items.

Availability of items in the market.

Shelf life of the item.

Seasonality of the item.

Reorder quantity and Limit:

reorder quantity is the amount to be ordered while placing a new purchase order. As far as the "Reorder" limit, certain parameters shall be considered such as the minimum limit, operation quantities needed during a period starting from the requisitioning until receiving items at warehouses, availability in markets, requisitions not yet ordered, and orders not yet delivered.

Safety Stock:

is the reserved extra stock of an item which shall be stored in the warehouse to prevent stock-out. Calculation of safety stock shall be done by inventory practitioner in collaboration with the end-user and shall consider costs of safety stock, volatility of the demand, value of the item, product shelf life or any other relevant consideration.

Strategic Stock:

Strategic stocks are held as part of a deliberate strategy to achieve specific Entity objectives

.

Entities, when required, shall define strategic stocks based on a comprehensive assessment of, but not limited to, operational needs, potential risks, and supply chain vulnerabilities.

Maximum and minimum stock limits:

shall be defined and maintained by the inventory practitioner in collaboration with the Warehouse/end-user and all shall be recorded in warehouses’ records while taking the following into consideration:

When calculating the minimum stock limit, special attention shall be made to the time to deliver each article from local or foreign sources, in addition to purchase procedures and consumption rates of the same according to operation schedules including the required repair and maintenance plans.

The maximum stock limit of every article shall not, whenever possible, exceed the average consumption rate of one year. Certain factors shall be considered such as how stocking appropriateness, exposure to damage, available in markets, specifications amendment, price fluctuations, supply requisitions not yet ordered, and orders not yet delivered.

sections.title: 5.11.5 Slow moving, Redundant and Surplus Items
sections.content:
5.11.5 Slow moving, Redundant and Surplus Items

Items not moved in term of receiving or issues as per warehouses records for the designated retention period shall be considered Slow Moving. The retention period is determined by the Entity’s based on the nature of the items, inventory turnover and general strategy.

Items that are damaged, expired or with great affected physical condition shall be considered redundant or obsolete.

Warehouse practitioners are responsible for monitoring the expiry dates of materials. Items with the nearest expiration dates should be prioritised for issuance.

In case of any item quality issue identified such as unexpected physical condition or damage to an item, the Warehouse practitioners shall promptly report the discrepancy.

Based on the evaluation of the items, the appropriate provision and course of action shall be defined by the Inspection Committee, which include write off, scrapping, disposal, or other measures as deemed suitable (refer to Finance Policy and Section 5 for further information)

The inventory practitioners are strongly encouraged to collaborate with other Entities to check if these items can still be used or repurposed by another Entity based on their demand, before disposing or scrapping. Stock transfer shall be performed by Warehouse practitioners.

If no Entity is interested in the items, the item shall be written off for disposal through a sales auction or any other disposal method in accordance with regulation (refer to Section 5).
hierarchy: 5.11.5 Slow moving, Redundant and Surplus Items

sections.title: 5.11.6 Warehouse Management
sections.content: 5.11.6 Warehouse Management

sections.title: 5.11.6.1 General Warehouse Provision
sections.content:
5.11.6.1 General Warehouse Provision

The Entity may opt to have or not to have warehouses.

If the Entity decides to use warehouses, it must:

Inform Finance and the Department of Government Enablement.

Abide by the policies and procedures provided for in this document.

Warehouses can be managed by Entities directly or outsourced to third-party providers.

The government Entity shall use pre-approved forms to document all stock movements in terms of additions, deductions, returns and transfers.

sections.title: 5.11.6.2 Receiving, Stocking, and Issuing Stock Items
sections.content:
5.11.6.2 Receiving, Stocking, and Issuing Stock Items

The warehouse practitioner, shall upon receipt of "Stock Items", inspect such items and match them with purchase order or call-off orders in term of quantities and specifications. If technical experience is needed for inspection, assistance from an experienced officer or a committee of experienced individuals may be sought when large quantity or high value items arrive to warehouse. The value criterion shall be included in resolution setting up the committee formation.

Suppliers must follow specified terms in the PO or contract when delivering items, including packaging and documentation requirements. This includes providing comprehensive documentation for goods receipt, such as item guarantees, specifications, serial number, and other necessary details as outlined in the PO or contract

A paper or electronic receipt voucher of received items and matched with the specifications shall be made. Such items shall be kept in the warehouse recorded in warehouse records while value plus quantity is recorded in the accounting records.

Surplus or items do not comply with specifications as per the purchase order or call-off order shall be kept separately as a preliminary step to returning or replacement, as the case may be. This shall be advised by Procurement to the supplier and to the Finance section in the government Entity.

Stock Items shall be issued to user sections by an electronic or paper store issue vouchers. Issued items shall be priced according to the approved Finance Policy. Value of issued items shall be deducted from the appropriate budget item, as well as recording value and quantity in warehouse and accounting records.

Items returned to warehouses after issuance shall be recorded by an electronic or paper return voucher with the value thereof deducted from the same relevant issuance item under which such items have previously been deducted. Value and quantity of returned articles shall be added to warehouses and accounting books.

Each item shall be kept in the warehouses separately as appropriate to work needs ensuring applying the of "first in first out". Only low value or large size, not sensitive to weather conditions and not affected by long storage period should be kept in open places or unroofed warehouses which shall protect by securing against weather and similar conditions. Suitable roofing methods and wood bases shall be furnished to such warehouses for protection. For safety purposes, warehouses shall be high walled and well-guarded.

The Warehouse practitioners shall exercise caution to stock used items separately from new ones. Petrol and inflammable materials shall be stocked in special purpose warehouses.
hierarchy: 5.11.6.2 Receiving, Stocking, and Issuing Stock Items

sections.title: 5.11.6.3 Receiving of Direct Consumption Purchases Materials
sections.content:
5.11.6.3 Receiving of Direct Consumption Purchases Materials

For Entities that do not have their own warehouses, direct consumption purchases materials shall be initially received in a special purpose location, otherwise alternative receipt procedures shall be followed. Based on the nature of materials, they shall be immediately delivered or notified to the concerned section.

Received items shall be inspected by the requisitioning user section to match specifications and quantities to the purchase order or call-off order.

An electronic receipt voucher shall be made by the requisitioning user section of actual quantities received which comply with specifications. The value of such items shall be charged to the appropriate budget item.

Overage or items which do not comply with specifications as per the purchase order or call-off order shall be kept separately as a preliminary step to return or replace, as the case may be. This shall be notified by Procurement to the supplier and to the Finance section.
hierarchy: 5.11.6.3 Receiving of Direct Consumption Purchases Materials

sections.title: 5.11.6.4 Subcontracting and Supplier Managed Inventory
sections.content:
5.11.6.4 Subcontracting and Supplier Managed Inventory

If applicable, subcontracting or Supplier Managed Inventory (SMI) may be considered for certain inventory items based on cost-effectiveness, lead times, and other strategic factors.

Agreements for these inventory management shall define the contracting period, reordering responsibilities, minimum and maximum stock levels, and required terms and conditions.

The decision to subcontract shall be approved as per the delegation of authority and Finance and Procurement shall be informed.

sections.title: 5.11.7 Warehouse Stocktaking
sections.content: 5.11.7 Warehouse Stocktaking

sections.title: 5.11.7.1 Warehouse annual Stocktaking
sections.content:
5.11.7.1 Warehouse annual Stocktaking

Every government Entity that has its own warehouses shall carry out a total stocktaking of all contents at least once annually, without prejudice to the perpetual and surprise stocktaking system during the year.

It is advised to conduct regular validations to assess the quantity, expiry date, and quality of the inventory.

Total annual Stocktaking starts on 15 December of each year and shall be accomplished by end of the following month (January). If work circumstances in some warehouses necessitates the continuous operation without stocktaking, balances shall be verified and reinstated by addition and deduction of stock movements.

During Warehouse annual Stocktaking, the Warehouse practitioners shall be responsible of verifying the authenticity and accurateness of the warehouse records, comparing the actual stock levels of the items stored in the warehouse against the records.

Finance shall be responsible of estimating and depreciating the value of the stored items, with collaborative support from the Warehouse and Inventory practitioners.

A committee for annual stocktaking shall be set up by the appropriate authority level upon a recommendation by the finance and after consultation with the user sections.

Membership of the annual stocktaking committee shall represent technical and finance units, applying segregation of duties principle. Stocktaking shall be carried out in attendance of the warehouse practitioner.

For further details regarding inventory valuation, stocktaking committee, and inventory reconciliation please refer to the Finance Policy.

Stocktaking committees shall prepare lists of items physically counted and compare with book balances. Any shortage or surplus shall be noted in the stocktaking lists.

Stocktaking lists shall be prepared according to the pre-approved form for this purpose.

A copy of the stocktaking list shall be submitted to the Head of Finance in the government Entity to review shortages and surpluses. In case of financial or administrative contraventions, the matter shall be referred to the appropriate authority level for taking necessary disciplinary action against whoever is responsible as provided for in the Civil Service Law.

In case of shortage or surplus, the causes thereof shall be reported by the government Entity to Finance to settle the differences by addition and deductions after investigating reasons of the discrepancy. The government Entity shall not make any amendment to warehouse records until Finance decides in this regard.

In case of shortage or damage of items beyond control of the warehouse practitioner, such items shall be deducted from the stock balance by approval of the appropriate authority level and the validation from the Finance.

Stocktaking committees shall report on warehouses stocktaking noting any irregularities or differences and in particular:

Errors in items description or classification.

Items in bad condition or insufficient storing.

Errors in records.

Items need special protection.

Items with expired validity.

Recommendations to avoid errors and remove obstacles.

Annual Stocktaking lists shall be kept in a special file for references as needed.

Stocktaking committees shall report on warehouses stocktaking noting any irregularities or differences and in particular:

Errors in items description or classification.

Items in bad condition or insufficient storing.

Errors in records.

Items need special protection.

Items with expired validity.

Recommendations to avoid errors and remove obstacles.

Annual Stocktaking lists shall be kept in a special file for references as needed.

sections.title: 5.11.7.2 Perpetual and Surprise Stocktaking
sections.content:
5.11.7.2 Perpetual and Surprise Stocktaking

In coordination with the Finance and internal audit unit, a committee set up by the Undersecretary, or equivalent, shall carry out a surprise count according to perpetual or other stocktaking program developed for this purpose.

In case of shortage or surplus, the causes thereof shall be reported by the government Entity to the Finance to settle the differences by addition and deductions after investigating reasons thereto. The government Entity shall not make any amendment to warehouse records until Finance decides in this regard.

In case of shortage or damage of items beyond control of the warehouse practitioner, such items shall be deducted from the stock balance by approval of the appropriate authority level. Finance shall be advised thereof.

sections.title: 6 Procurement Charter
sections.content: 6 Procurement Charter

sections.title: 6.1 Introduction
sections.content:
6.1 Introduction

The Procurement Charter defines roles and committees required for the procurement operations and mechanism of governance.

The Procurement Charter defines the committees required for the procurement operations, in particular the roles and responsibilities of the Procurement Committee and the Technical Evaluation Team.

The head of the Procurement shall ensure that procurement operations are in accordance with the Procurement Charter.

The intended audience of the Procurement Charter is the executive management and stakeholders involved in procurement activities.

sections.title: 6.2 Organisation of the Procurement Function
sections.content: 6.2 Organisation of the Procurement Function

sections.title: 6.2.1 Roles in the Procurement Function
sections.content:
6.2.1 Roles in the Procurement Function

The procurement practitioners, understood as the employees of the government Entity involved in procuring or making procurement decisions, shall be assigned to standard procurement roles defined in this charter, considering the following:

Multiple procurement practitioners may be assigned to one standard procurement role, except the role of the Head of Procurement.

A particular procurement practitioner may be assigned to more than one standard procurement role considering that the principle of segregation of duties is maintained at the individual level. In cases where duty segregation cannot be achieved fully, the individual conducting these duties must obtain approval for all the activities that are not segregated.

The standard procurement roles perform key activities enabling procurement function to fulfil its assigned duties and expected outputs.

The activities stated for each standard procurement role form the minimum responsibilities, which procurement practitioners should fulfil. They are in addition to other assigned organisational responsibilities.

The standard procurement roles are divided into strategic, transactional and support roles.

sections.title: 6.2.2 Strategic Roles
sections.content:
6.2.2 Strategic Roles

The Head of Procurement

Represent the procurement function at the executive level.

Accountable for managing relationships with internal stakeholders.

Ensure the procurement function operates in compliance with the Procurement Framework and the applicable laws and regulations.

Define the procurement strategy, including the strategic goals and objectives, vision and mission of Procurement and Green/Sustainable Procurement goals.

Manage internal budget of the procurement function.

Manage procurement practitioners and their competencies.

Champion change and communication, processes and tools that improve the performance of the procurement function.

Setup and monitor performance targets of procurement practitioners.

Ensure continuing professional development of procurement practitioners.

Recommend recruitment of procurement practitioners.

Monitor and manage the performance of the procurement function and address opportunity areas to deliver savings, increase efficiencies and effectiveness, and enhance Green/Sustainable Procurement practices.

Report to the executive level on performance of the procurement function biannually.

Maintain quality assurance and improvement program that covers all aspects of the procurement function and obtain its approval from the Procurement Committee.

Accountable for demand consolidation activity and its results.

Endorse the members of the Evaluation Team for each relevant tender.
