Manage the exception approvals such as splitting of the procurement requirement, bypassing supplier negotiations and endorsing sole source and single source tendering before required approvals are obtained as per the PDoA.

Approve the supplier segmentation criteria and supplier performance metric.

Sponsor the development of relationship/partnership with strategic suppliers.

Category Specialist

Validate the category structure & segmentation.

Maintain understanding of industry developments, marketplace trends, emerging technology and leading practices for the category.

Develop & implement category strategies to achieve savings and efficiencies over the short-term & long-term horizon and drive category development.

Identify opportunities for cost savings and demand optimisation in the category, and develop category sourcing requirements.

Collaborate with internal stakeholders and end-users for procuring goods, services and projects, which meet desired requirements.

Coordinate execution of strategic sourcing initiatives for the category, support supplier screening and selection, and  negotiate & finalise agreements with suppliers.

Participate in validation of the technical and commercial evaluation results for supplier bids.

Perform benefit tracking for the category, analyse improvement potential, and ensure that savings targets are met.

Measure and report the results of strategic sourcing initiatives, resulting benefits and savings.

Endorse requests for amendments, extensions and renewals of contracts.

Endorse change requests by suppliers and penalties, liquidated damages and financial deductions applicable on supplier.

Establish new and maintain relationships with strategic suppliers.

Coordinate development and execution of supplier management strategies including supplier segmentation, relationship management and supplier collaboration.

Monitor supplier performance and risk, track progress of improvement actions and conduct performance & risk evaluation meetings with suppliers.

sections.title: 6.2.3 Transactional Roles
sections.content:
6.2.3 Transactional Roles

Procurement Manager

Collaborate with the end-user for implementation of the Procurement Plan.

Supervise the transactional (Green) procurement initiatives and ensure agreed SLAs and KPIs are met.

Approve post-factum purchase orders, no- purchase order purchases, purchase orders amendments and purchase orders cancellations.

Manage disputes with suppliers related to supply of goods, services and projects.

Lead reduction of transactional buying through quantitative and qualitative feedback to end-user on opportunities for contacting and enabling e-catalogues.

Sourcing Lead

Ensure offers received are appropriately evaluated.

Approve release, amendments and closeout of purchase orders.

Endorse post-factum purchase orders, no- purchase order purchases, purchase orders amendments and purchase orders cancellations.

Liaise with suppliers for resolution of disputes related to goods, services and projects.

Collaborate with Finance to facilitate the release of payments to the suppliers in a timely and accurate manner.

Collaborate with internal stakeholders and end-users for their requirements of low value purchases through quick sourcing.

Propose improvement initiatives based on observations made by all specialists.

Propose Green/Sustainable Procurement initiatives.

Collaborate with vendors to drive Green/Sustainable Procurement initiatives.

Support in reduction of transactional buying through quantitative and qualitative feedback on opportunities for contacting and enabling e-catalogues.

Maintain and update the e-catalogues in collaboration with category leads.

Sourcing Specialist

Verify purchase requisitions against existing contracts and inventories to identify if the requirement can be fulfilled without entering new obligations.

Collaborate with Category Specialist for purchase requisition requiring strategic sourcing and support in its execution.

Execute quick sourcing of low value non-strategic items.

Manage conversion of purchase requisitions to purchase orders including their generation and release.

Ensure that purchase orders and invoices include sufficient granular information and are linked to correct general ledger accounts, cost centres and procurement category.

Follow-up on overdue purchase orders.

Manage amendments, updates, close-out and cancellation of purchase orders.

Support in creating, updating and managing e-catalogues.

sections.title: 6.2.4 Support Roles
sections.content:
6.2.4 Support Roles

Contracting Specialist

Support in reviewing changes to standard contract templates requested by end-users or suppliers.

Support preparation of new contracts, contract amendments, renewals and extensions.

Verify and endorse change request raised by suppliers for ongoing contracts.

Endorse application of penalties, liquidated damages and financial deductions in accordance to the provisions of the contracts.

Provide paralegal advice and participate in discussions related to sourcing and procurement including dispute resolution.

Coordinate and obtain endorsement from Legal for all the aforementioned tasks.

Supplier Relationship Management Specialist

Encourage suppliers to keep their registration details and qualification status up-to-date and resolve business queries related to supplier lifecycle management.

Manage the recording and reporting of supplier performance, including but not limited to sustainability practices and initiatives.

Launch supplier performance surveys and coordinate with stakeholders for response.

Create and publish supplier performance scorecards.

Ensure all components of supplier performance are regularly updated and relevant stakeholders have access to the information.

Process any changes requested in the supplier performance survey and scorecard.

Support in supplier segmentation as per defined segmentation criteria.

Support in coordinating improvement action plan to suppliers and tracking their progress, including but not limited to sustainability practices and initiatives.

Support in supplier relationship management activities.

Reporting Expert

Publish reports related to measuring and tracking procurement performance at established frequency to relevant stakeholders.

Process any changes requested in reporting requirements and ensure implementation of approved requirements.

Monitor the availability and health of reporting data and highlight any irregularities.

Support in monitoring all action plans for the procurement function and tracking their progress.

Generate Green/Sustainable Procurement reporting and ensure compliance with latest sustainability related reporting requirements.

Coordinators for collaboration between Entities and Gov. Procurement

Support in local implementation of contracts related to common categories issued by Gov. Procurement.

Resolve queries related to common categories and their contracts with support of Gov. Procurement, if needed.

Support in monitoring data quality locally, assess issues and root cause of poor quality and implementing improvement actions.

Coordinate with Gov. Procurement for changes in supplier and item master.

Identify, communicate and resolve resistance and queries related to change with the support of Gov. Procurement, when needed.

Ensure requirements and readiness for change implementation in collaboration with Gov. Procurement, including the on-going transition to Green/Sustainable Procurement.

sections.title: 6.3 Procurement Committee
sections.content: 6.3 Procurement Committee

sections.title: 6.3.1 Purpose
sections.content:
6.3.1 Purpose

The Procurement Committee shall assist the Chairman in fulfilling the oversight responsibilities related to the Procurement function.

The established Procurement Committee shall supervise the operations of the procurement function, monitor its performance and compliance with the regulatory and operational frameworks for the procurement, including Green/Sustainable Procurement goals & initiatives.

It shall be responsible for endorsing the strategic direction proposed by the head of the Procurement, providing oversight of key procurement initiatives and managing redressal of issues related to the procurement function.

sections.title: 6.3.2 Composition
sections.content:
6.3.2 Composition

The Procurement Committee shall be established as a permanent committee and the Chairman shall appoint its members by name.

The composition of the Procurement Committee shall be as per below.

Additional members may be appointed to the Procurement Committee, on temporary basis, as replacement for an existing member.

These temporary members (acting members) shall be from the same function as the original member and will have same authority and responsibilities.

The members of the Procurement Committee shall be conversant with the Procurement Framework.

The duties and responsibilities of the committee members shall be in addition to their organisational roles.

The Procurement Committee shall be accountable and report directly to the Chairman.

The chairperson or members of the Procurement Committee may be dismissed by the Chairman on the following grounds:

Lack of independence, conflict of interest or failure to declare conflict interest.

Any other reason that the Chairman may deem to be just and credible.

sections.title: 6.3.3 Delegated Authority
sections.content:
6.3.3 Delegated Authority

The following authority shall be delegated to the Procurement Committee:

The authority to require any employee of the government Entity or any other authorised party acting on behalf or with the government Entity, involved in activities preceding procurement and procurement execution including tendering and contract management to attend meeting of the committee and provide information or explanation required by the Committee.

The authority to obtain independent legal or professional advice from subject matter experts with relevant experience.

The authority to liaise with internal and independent auditors if evidence of non-compliance to regulations or Procurement framework is discovered.

The authority to make decisions regarding internal or external grievances raised against the Procurement function.

sections.title: 6.3.4 Key Responsibilities
sections.content:
6.3.4 Key Responsibilities

Approve various procurement operations as mandated by the PDoA, including but not limited to evaluation of proposed contract amendments, extension, renewal, and terminations and the cancelation of open tenders.

Review the Procurement Management Report

Monitor compliance of the procurement function with the regulatory and operational frameworks and relevant government legislations.

Supervise Green/Sustainable Procurement initiatives.

Any matter, task or responsibility delegated by the Chairman.

sections.title: 6.3.5 Meetings and Quorum
sections.content:
6.3.5 Meetings and Quorum

The Procurement Committee shall convene at least once every month. Furthermore, the chairperson of the Procurement Committee may call additional meetings deemed necessary to address important matters referred to the committee by the head of the Procurement or in respect of matters that the Committee at its discretion wishes to pursue to discharge its assigned responsibilities.

Documents, reports, presentations and any other submissions shall be circulated to the Procurement Committee members and other invitees under reasonable time before the proposed meeting date or earlier if required.

The Committee may elect to conduct meetings by telephone or videoconference provided all Procurement Committee members involved in the meeting are able to participate in the discussion.

The minimum quorum for any meeting will be two-third voting members attending in person or via teleconference or videoconference (rounded up to the nearest whole number).

The duration of the meetings should allow adequate discussion of the issues.

In the absence of the chairperson, the Procurement Committee shall elect a Member present to chair the meeting.

sections.title: 6.3.6 Procurement Committee Decisions
sections.content:
6.3.6 Procurement Committee Decisions

The Procurement Committee shall endeavour to make decisions based on unanimous consensus.

In case unanimous consensus is not reached, the decision shall be made based on majority vote of members present in the meeting in person or via teleconference or videoconference.

In case of tie vote the chairperson of the Procurement Committee shall exercise his/her vote to break the tie.

The Procurement Committee may adopt resolution by circulation without meeting, provided all members of the Procurement Committee endorse the resolution.

sections.title: 6.3.7 Work Programme
sections.content:
6.3.7 Work Programme

The Committee shall prepare a work programme detailing the items expected to be considered in the fiscal year.

The work programme shall be a living document, updated after each meeting adding additional items for consideration of the Procurement Committee.

Review of the work programme shall be the standing agenda item in every meeting.

The secretary of the Procurement Committee shall support in creation of the work programme.

sections.title: 6.3.8 Reporting
sections.content:
6.3.8 Reporting

The minutes and actions of each meeting shall be prepared by the secretary and circulated after approval of the chairperson of the Procurement Committee within five (5) working days to all the attendees of the meeting and Chairman.

The Procurement Committee shall prepare and submit to Chairman bi-annual report covering, at the minimum:

Open points and matters requiring decision or attention of the Chairman.

Status of the work programme of the committee indicating completed and pending items for the fiscal year.

Summary of the performance of the procurement function presented by Head of Procurement, including but not limited to the Sustainability/Green procurement practices & initiatives

Individual attendance of committee members and the chairperson of Procurement Committee.

Exercise of the delegated power of authority by the committee.

Non-compliance of the procurement function and actions taken.

sections.title: 6.4 Evaluation Team
sections.content: 6.4 Evaluation Team

sections.title: 6.4.1 Purpose
sections.content:
6.4.1 Purpose

The Evaluation Team promotes cross-functional collaboration and is engaged for relevant tenders as per the PDoA.

The established Evaluation Team shall facilitate the selection of the most competent suppliers in compliance with the Revised Procurement Framework, Green Procurement objectives and applicable laws and regulations.

sections.title: 6.4.2 Constitution
sections.content:
6.4.2 Constitution

The members of the Evaluation Team shall be appointed by authorised parties as per the PDoA and endorsed by the head of the Procurement for each relevant tender.

The members of the Evaluation Team must have adequate knowledge regarding the goods, services and projects or required subject matter expertise to provide meaningful input to the tender process.

The Evaluation Team may have one or more than one of the following roles:

End-user department representative

Finance expert

Legal expert

Subject matter expert

The members of the Evaluation Team shall be conversant with the Procurement Framework, Procurement Gate, applicable laws and regulations.

The duties and responsibilities of the team members shall be in addition to their organisational roles.

The members of the Evaluation Team may be dismissed on the following grounds:

Any other reason that the head of the Procurement may deem to be just and credible.

sections.title: 6.4.3 Delegated Authority
sections.content:
6.4.3 Delegated Authority

The following authority shall be delegated to the Evaluation Team:

The authority to negotiate with suppliers on behalf of the organisation.

The authority to seek information from relevant internal stakeholders for understanding the tender and its scope, evaluation and negotiation guidelines.

sections.title: 6.4.4 Key Responsibilities
sections.content:
6.4.4 Key Responsibilities

Provide inputs for developing the sourcing strategy, including but not limited to Green Procurement requirements.

Evaluate the tenders in fair and ethical manner as per the established evaluation criteria.

Negotiate with suppliers on behalf of the organisation as per the established guidelines.

Communicate with suppliers through communication channel available in Procurement Gate maintaining fairness and transparency.

Declare the Conflict of Interest that may have arisen.

Hold information received as part of supplier’s bid in the strictest confidence and not release this information outside of the Evaluation Team.

Maintain probity of its actions.

Any matter, task or responsibility delegated by the Head of Procurement.

sections.title: 6.4.5 Meetings and Quorum
sections.content:
6.4.5 Meetings and Quorum

The Evaluation Team shall hold meetings deemed necessary to address matters related to providing inputs for sourcing strategy, evaluation of tenders and conducting negotiations.

The Team may elect to conduct meetings by telephone or videoconference provided all Evaluation Team members involved in the meeting are able to participate in the discussion.

The attendance of all Evaluation Team members is required for each meeting, either in person or via teleconference or videoconference.

The duration of the meetings should allow adequate discussion of the issues.

sections.title: 6.4.6 Evaluation Team Decisions
sections.content:
6.4.6 Evaluation Team Decisions

The Evaluation Team decisions must be recorded in the Digital Procurement Platform.

sections.title: 6.4.7 Work Programme
sections.content:
6.4.7 Work Programme

The Team will prepare a work programme when it is appointed for the relevant tender.

The work programme shall be a living document, updated after each meeting.

Review of the work programme shall be the standing agenda item in every meeting.

sections.title: 6.4.8 Reporting
sections.content:
6.4.8 Reporting

The Evaluation Team shall nominate one of its members to prepare minutes and actions of each meeting circulated within five (5) working days to all the attendees of the meeting and the Head of Procurement.

The Evaluation Team may be required to justify and explain the rationale behind its approach and the evaluation by the Head of Procurement and internal or external auditors.

The Evaluation Team shall submit any additional reports required by the head of the Procurement.

sections.title: 7 Procurement Processes
sections.content: 7 Procurement Processes

sections.title: 8 Sales Auctions
sections.content:
8 Sales Auctions

Sales Auctions are a recommended course of action to dispose of slow moving, redundant or obsolete stock to ensure any remaining value shall be retrieved from these materials. The Sales Auctions are to take place as soon as possible after identifying eligible stock. The execution of Sales Auctions shall take place in accordance with government guidelines, the Procurement Policy, the Finance Policy, and direction from the involved Committees.

sections.title: 8.1 Sales Auction
sections.content:
8.1 Sales Auction

The sales auction may be announced publicly provided that the announcement shall include the details and specifications of the items offered for sale.

Sales Auction shall be based on three governing principles: announcement, equality and free competition. Financial authority limits relating to the Sales Auction indicate to the original purchase cost of the materials and equipment proposed to be disposed of and not to the expected proceeds of sale.

sections.title: 8.2 Inspection Committee
sections.content:
8.2 Inspection Committee

After the completion of writing off procedures and before disposal of fixed assets and materials records which are no more economically useful, damaged or slow-moving items, empty containers and scrap it shall be presented to a special advisory committee at each government Entity called the "Inspection Committee".

This Committee shall be formed of four or five members with the appropriate experience from among the government Entity staff. Inspection Committee shall assume the assessment of the condition and estimated sale value, make recommendations for the method of sale either by a sales auction, through sealed envelopes or by any other means of disposal for the equipment and materials regardless their purchase cost. Such committee shall submit its recommendations in respect of the above to Procurement or equivalent at the government Entity for guidance.

Inspection Committee shall ensure that the inspection site is convenient for those who are interested to participate in the Sales Auction and that the arrangement and display are adequate with the aim to provide the opportunity for inspection before participating in the Sales Auction, obtain the best offers and provide the greatest deal of transparency and competitiveness.

The submissions to Procurement Committees in respect of the sale of assets and materials must include the contents of the Inspection Committee reports.
